trans-unit.source: Sample text - This is an ideal place to enrich your learner's understanding of your topic. Enter as much or as little text here as you want.
You can insert a brief summary of the module here...

Do you agree with this statement?

Navigation

Forward/Back arrows: Press on the Forward and Back arrows to move through the course one screen at a time.

Menu button: Pressing the Menu button opens up a list of all of the screens in the course. Pressing on a screen title in the list allows you to jump straight to the specific screen you want.

Learning Content

Interaction buttons: There will often be buttons within the learning content area on each screen (e.g. MORE or SUBMIT). Press on these to move through a series of slides, explore hotspots on an interactive diagram, or answer questions.

Hyperlinks: At some points in the course there may be hyperlinks to external resources. Pressing on these opens a new window in your browser which you must close or minimise to return to the main course.

Are you sure you want to Close the course?

Click Back to return to the course or Close Course to close the course.
We've sent you an email with your unique course link, you can now close this window.
To set the correct answer for a blank - just edit the text within the field
To add multiple correct answers simply separate them by commas.

TOPIC ONE: What's your easy mistake?
5 common mistakes: Which one's your bad? What's the risk?

TOPIC TWO: Data is just data, isn't it?
Try some real-life challenges to see if you dish the right data.
Data protection, it’s probably not for you.

Yes it’s the law, and you have to do the training, but as long as your company policy stays on the right side of it, and you stick with that, all is well, right?

Before you judge whether it’s for you or not, take a look at these 5 easy mistakes company employees make, everyday.


Big deal, or no deal at all?
See if your colleagues agree with you.
You meant to send an email about a customer to your colleague, Dave P, but sent it to Dave B, a different customer, instead.
How would you rate this mistake?
Sending customer info to the wrong recipient is the top reason for data breaches in the UK. Yet with predictive text, it’s extra easy to do.
Sharing is caring, but not when it comes to customer info.

The Chief Constable of Dyfed-Powys Police accidentally sent an email to the wrong person, containing personal data. He was fined £150,000 by the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO). You can read about it here, on their website.


Equally, Chelsea Hospital used ‘CC’ instead of ‘BCC’ on an email thread, and was fined £180,000 for sharing highly sensitive personal information about a group of HIV patients.
How sure are you that you’ve always sent the right files to the right place?
Here's how you rated this mistake:

{{chart.5c12350ad9bfe.same_as_you_percentage}} of people thought the same as you.

Now move on for another easy mistake.
Have a look at how others answered:
You leave your coat on the train, with your work phone in it.
How would you rate this mistake?
It’s the key way employees help others get hold of data and the second biggest reason for data breaches in the UK.
So easy to do, but it happens way too often.

Having an un-secure mobile leaves it open to hacks.
Bags also contain documents and notes.

Whilst you may not deal with such sensitive data, a health worker who accidentally left a document behind at a client’s house, revealed case details that negatively impacted the lives of more than one family. There's similar stories here.

But actually, it’s not all about how the info is used by others - enabling others to get their hands on it at all is the crime.
Sure your data is safe when those oops moments happen?
Here's how you rated this mistake:

{{chart.5c12350adcbff.same_as_you_percentage}} of people thought the same as you.

Now move on for another easy mistake.
Have a look at how others answered:
You find some customer files at the bottom of your drawer, and can’t quite remember how long they’ve been there.
How would you rate this mistake?

This goes for data hanging around on your computer and in online files. Why? You can only keep personal info, and relevant parts of it, for a certain reason and timeframe. But also, because someone else could use it.
Having personal data lying around, even if you’re not directly sharing it, is in itself a breach of the laws.
Hampshire County Council was hit with a £100,000 fine by the Information Commissioner’s Office after documents containing personal details of over 100 people were found in a disused building.
Here's how you rated this mistake:

{{chart.5c12350adf8d7.same_as_you_percentage}} of people thought the same as you.

Now move on for another easy mistake.
Have a look at how others answered:
Clicked an email link you’re not totally convinced you should have?
How would you rate this mistake?

They’re often caused because individuals don’t update their anti-virus software, use non-encrypted devices - perhaps their own, or click dodgy links sent through to email addresses.

Without even knowing it, you could be leaking data to hackers using malware or data phishing.
Cyber attacks aren’t just the stuff of NetFlix series, but happen everyday.

This is the type of breach that is fined the most. Notching up £1,885,000 of fines over the last two years.


A telecoms company has just been issued with a record £400,000 fine by the ICO for security failings that allowed a cyber attacker to access customer data “with ease”. Read about it here.
Are you on your guard against cyber attacks?
Here's how you rated this mistake:

{{chart.5c12350ae298b.same_as_you_percentage}} of people thought the same as you.

Now move on for another easy mistake.
Have a look at how others answered:
You’re asked to send a marketing message about a new product to people who haven’t asked for you to keep in touch.
How would you rate this mistake?

Well, using data like names and numbers misappropriately is a serious breach of the act.

Especially when you’re trying to sell them something! More sharketing than marketing - sending out recorded messages or contacting people when they haven’t signed up for contact in this way, is data misuse.
We all get those pesky marketing calls and texts, so what’s the big deal?
A claims management company that made 17.5 million calls asking people if they had suffered hearing loss at work has been fined £250,000 by the ICO. Read the story, amongst plenty others, here.
This one kind of depends on your job role, but are you convinced you’ve never used customer data for ‘other reasons’?
Here's how you rated this mistake:

{{chart.5c12350ae5a0e.same_as_you_percentage}} of people thought the same as you.

Now move on for a summary.
Have a look at how others answered:
Don’t let data out the door

It’s likely we have all made or are at risk of making one of these five easy mistakes.

Behind every breach is a seriously red face.

So make sure you’re not the one letting data out the door.


Take control. Pick the mistakes that most likely apply to you, and find out some easy steps to avoid them.

When you’re sharing any customer data, double check who you are sending it to.

This goes for emails, phone calls and letters.

When you share information internally, ask yourself if that person should have all the customer data you have. Should you filter some out? See the next topic to understand what data is OK to use.

We can all forget things or be the victim of stealing. So, take action to:

  • Put a lock on your mobile devices so data isn’t easy to access
  • Encrypt your devices - ask IT for help
  • Put a tracker on your mobile or tablet - so it can be found
  • Only carry printed or written data where absolutely necessary
  • Use password protected cloud storage to access data files when working remotely

Ensure your work environment has safe places for data to be kept and managed.

  • Don’t print customer data unless you really need to
  • Set reminders on your calendar to delete it - you can only legally keep relevant data for the time you absolutely need it
  • Delete or destroy data safely - shred don’t bin
  • Regularly clear out customer data on your computer and servers - it’s not just about printed data storage

Chat with IT to feel confident you're not at risk of cyber attacks

  • Update your anti-virus software regularly
  • BYOD? - Check your own devices are encrypted and have anti-virus software installed
  • Never respond to suspicious emails. If concerned, call the company they are being sent from to be sure they’re genuine
  • If you worry you’ve clicked something you shouldn’t - shout for help!

Customer data can only be used for a specific, agreed to, task.

Unless customers have agreed to be contacted for the purpose you want to get in touch - don’t do it.

This includes recorded marketing messages.


Now check out the other topic so you know what kind of data you can deal with.

Stopping data leaks is just one side of data protection. If you’re dealing with data, it has to be the right kind. Wrong data usage also breaks the law.

To avoid being a data PRAT, here’s four points to remember.

PURPOSE

You can store data for a specific purpose only e.g. for health records or to run a credit check

RELEVANT

The data you keep must be relevant and not excessive to that purpose

ACCURATE

If you keep it, keep it accurate - wrong data is bad data

TIME

Only keep it for the time you actually need it
See if you can do it right in the following challenges.

Lindy, who works at a car retailer, has just successfully sold a car to Mr Phillips. It was part-exchange, and he paid the remainder in cash. He’s driven the car away today. What data on Mr Phillips can Lindy keep?

Keep it:

She’s sold the car already, so you could argue she doesn’t need any details. But keeping a name, address and contact number, for a specific length of time (e.g. a year), is appropriate, in case Mr Phillips comes back with any queries or needs to use his warranty.

Lose it:

Bank details and credit check details should never have been obtained, since he paid in cash. But they certainly aren’t needed now. Driving license number is no longer needed. It’s purpose was to support the sale - and that’s done.
Think again about the purpose for keeping the data, and what is actually relevant to that purpose.
Think again about the purpose for keeping the data, and what is actually relevant to that purpose.

After completing a sale with a new customer, Tiago shares the news with his colleagues. The marketing team ask for details so they can sign the customer up for their regular product emails. What should Tiago do?
That might not be a good idea.
Avoid being a data PRAT by only sharing data where there’s customer consent and it’s relevant to the purpose.
